Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Understanding how genes are turned on and off is a major key to understanding life. There are many levels of gene regulation in biology, such as the decision to copy the DNA into a messenger RNA or the decisions that regulate how much protein is translated from the messenger RNA. This project focuses on another level of gene regulation, i.e. mRNA stability. The longer an mRNA stays around, the more protein can be made from it. Nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (NMD) is a mechanism that controls RNA stability. The NMD degradation pathway depends on the placement of signals in the RNA that stop protein translation; the shorter the protein that is made, the less stable the RNA. One way that mRNAs can gain stop signals is through alternative splicing; approximately one third of the genes that undergo alternative splicing generate an alternative messenger RNA that is preferentially destroyed by the NMD pathway. The main goal of this project is to study the regulation of the NMD pathway using the model organism, Caenorhabditis elegans. Specific aims are: 1) to understand the relationship between alternative splicing and NMD; 2) to identify molecules that control the NMD process; and 3) to probe the relationship between translational state (whether a mRNA is making protein or not) and efficiency of NMD. Because NMD is an important quality control mechanism for RNA in the cell, these studies will make important contributions to our understanding of gene regulation.

Broader Impacts: This project will provide training opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students. The experiments to be conducted in this project are perfect for introducing undergraduates to the excitement of research science. The laboratory has a history of recruiting undergraduates from underrepresented groups and will continue to do so in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits
To turn on a gene, the DNA must be copied into an RNA. However, before this RNA is translated into a protein sequence, internal parts of the RNA (called introns) are removed and flanking sequences called exons are pasted together by a process known as pre-mRNA splicing. In higher organisms, many genes can be spliced in different patterns and this process of alternative splicing is a common mechanism for generating multiple proteins from a single gene. Alternative splicing is highly regulated between different types of cells, allowing for even greater diversity to be generated from the genome in multicellular organims. This type of gene regulation also can activate a pathway called nonsense-mediated decay (NMD), in which forms of the gene generated by alternative splicing can be degraded if they encode proteins that are too short.

The microscopic worm, C. elegans, is the only animal model organism in which mutants in the NMD pathway are viable, and we had observed changes in alternative splicing patterns in NMD mutants. We have made progress to develop evidence that in these NMD mutants, shortened forms of proteins that regulate alternative splicing are stabilized and thus can further alter alternative splicing. As a result of our studies, we identified a situation in which the germ line in these worms (cells that produce sperm and eggs) has a consistent unusual alternative splicing event, called alternative 3' splicing; we found over 200 genes with similar regulation. In this process, there are adjacent sites that can be chosen to form the end of the intron. In cells of the body (somatic cells) the further site that gives the longer intron is chosen, while in germ cells, the closer site is chosen leading to smaller introns. The discovery of this type of splicing phenomenon has important implications for the mechanism by which the large cellular machinery that performs splicing, called the spliceosome, operates. We published a paper on this work in the prestigious genomics journal, Genome Research, in 2015 and we are continuing experiments to understand the mechanism of this alternative splicing event.

Broader Impacts
These research activities involved the training of undergraduate students, with an emphasis on underrepresented students. Eight undergraduates have worked on this project; Taylor Akers (a co-author on the Genome Research paper), Jed Humphries, Ernesto Vasquez, Diana Summers (now a PhD student at UCSF), Andrew MacRae (now a PhD student at UCSC), Ken Osterhoudt (entering a PhD program at UCSC in fall 2016) and Samira Yitiz. Elisabeth Carrillo, an undergraduate McNair Scholar at nearby California State University Monterey Bay (CSUMB) spent two summers working in our lab on this project and will be a PhD student at UCSC in the fall of 2016. She was awarded an NSF graduate fellowship proposal based on her research in our lab.  Zahler, in his role as Program Director for the NIH-funded UCSC Maximizing Access to Research Careers (MARC) program, has run laboratory workshops for the MARC/IMSD Summer Research Institute students (rising juniors) exploring bioinformatic approaches to genes and genomes using C. elegans as a model. James Matthew Ragle, a PhD student in the Zahler lab, successfully defended his PhD thesis for work on this project supported by this grant.
